name: Ada Lovelace
bio: Mathematician and the first computer programmer in history. Her insights into Charles Babbage’s Analytical Engine were visionary.

name: Ada Yonath
bio: Israeli crystallographer awarded the Nobel Prize in Chemistry for her work on the structure of the ribosome.

name: Barbara McClintock
bio: Geneticist who discovered transposable elements or 'jumping genes' in corn. She received a Nobel Prize for her work.

name: Bette Nesmith Graham
bio: Inventor of Liquid Paper correction fluid, which became a staple in offices worldwide.

name: Chien-Shiung Wu
bio: Experimental physicist who worked on the Manhattan Project and made critical discoveries in beta decay.

name: Dorothy Hodgkin
bio: Chemist who developed protein crystallography and won the Nobel Prize for her work on penicillin and vitamin B12.

name: Elizabeth Blackwell
bio: First woman to receive a medical degree in the United States and a pioneer in promoting education for women in medicine.

name: Emmy Noether
bio: Mathematician who developed Noether’s Theorem, a key principle in theoretical physics linking symmetry and conservation laws.

name: Florence Nightingale
bio: Pioneer of modern nursing, known for her work during the Crimean War and transforming hospital sanitation practices.

name: Gertrude Elion
bio: Pharmacologist and Nobel laureate who developed drugs to treat leukemia, herpes, AIDS, and more.

name: Grace Hopper
bio: Computer scientist and U.S. Navy rear admiral who developed the first compiler for a programming language.

name: Hedy Lamarr
bio: Hollywood actress and inventor of frequency-hopping spread spectrum technology, the foundation of Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

name: Hypatia
bio: Ancient Greek mathematician, astronomer, and philosopher—murdered for her intellect by a mob in Alexandria.

name: Jocelyn Bell Burnell
bio: Astrophysicist who discovered pulsars, though the Nobel Prize went to her male supervisor.

name: Katherine Johnson
bio: NASA mathematician who calculated trajectories for the first U.S. spaceflights, enabling John Glenn's orbit.

name: Lise Meitner
bio: Physicist who co-discovered nuclear fission but was denied a Nobel Prize that went solely to Otto Hahn.

name: Mae Jemison
bio: Engineer, physician, and the first African-American woman in space aboard the Space Shuttle Endeavour.

name: Marie Curie
bio: Physicist and chemist who discovered radium and polonium. First woman to win a Nobel Prize and the only person to win in two sciences.

name: Mary Jackson
bio: Mathematician and aerospace engineer who became NASA’s first Black female engineer.

name: Maryam Mirzakhani
bio: Iranian mathematician and the first woman to win the Fields Medal, the highest honor in mathematics.

name: Rachel Carson
bio: Marine biologist and author of 'Silent Spring,' which exposed the dangers of pesticides and launched the modern environmental movement.

name: Rosalind Franklin
bio: Chemist whose X-ray images revealed the structure of DNA. Her male colleagues received the Nobel after her death.

name: Tu Youyou
bio: Chinese pharmaceutical chemist who discovered artemisinin, a treatment for malaria that has saved millions of lives.

name: Mary Anning
bio: Fossil collector and paleontologist who discovered the first correctly identified ichthyosaur skeleton. Her contributions to science were often overlooked because of her gender and class.

name: Esther Lederberg
bio: Microbiologist who discovered the lambda bacteriophage and developed the replica plating technique. Her pioneering work laid the foundation for modern bacterial genetics.

name: Lydia Villa-Komaroff
bio: Molecular biologist and one of the first Mexican-American women in the U.S. to earn a doctorate in the sciences. Her work helped pioneer the use of bacteria to produce human insulin.

name: Mary Golda Ross
bio: The first known Native American female engineer and a trailblazer in aerospace design. She worked on top-secret space exploration missions during the space race.

name: Marie Van Brittan Brown
bio: Inventor of the first home security system. Her design laid the groundwork for modern CCTV and alarm systems.

name: Kalpana Chawla
bio: The first Indian-born woman in space. A NASA astronaut and aerospace engineer, she died tragically in the Columbia space shuttle disaster.

name: Margaret Keane
bio: Artist known for her 'big eyes' paintings, whose husband claimed credit for her work until she won a court case proving her authorship.

name: Marthe Gautier
bio: French pediatrician whose research led to the discovery of the chromosomal cause of Down syndrome, but her male colleague took credit.

name: Claudia Goldin
bio: Economist who pioneered research into womenâ€™s roles in the labor force. Her foundational work has often been overshadowed by male economists.

name: Jewel Plummer Cobb
bio: Biologist and cancer researcher who also fought to expand opportunities for women and minorities in science.

name: Trotula of Salerno
bio: Medieval physician whose groundbreaking texts on women's health were later attributed to male authors or dismissed as myth.
